abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Coal Engineering
            Project for Pakistan was successful. The project achieved
            many of its technical objectives, its impact has been
            significant, sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and
            Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, the Government, WAPDA, and
            the Association would have saved a great deal of time and
            effort, if instead of preparing and implementing a
            full-fledged project, the Project Preparation Facility had
            been used to fund the initial exploratory stages before
            launching the project. Second, in an exploratory project of
            this type, the Borrower and the Association should be alert
            to the need for immediate cancellation of subsequent stages
            of the project should they prove unnecessary. Lastly, the
            project confirms the wisdom of the staged approach towards
            expenditures on mineral exploration, which in this case
            evaluated a large coat basin with minimal expenditures and
            large savings of credit proceeds.
